keyTakeAways: A steel cable on the Glória funicular in Lisbon snapped during operation, causing a deadly crash that killed at least 16 people and injured several others.
The cable failed to meet the specifications set by CARRIS, the funicular's operator, and did not have the required certification to carry passengers.
The preliminary investigation by GPIAAF identified serious failures in the cable, maintenance, and braking systems.
Maintenance tasks were marked as completed even though they were not actually performed, and the maintenance plan was falsely recorded as compliant.
Eyewitnesses described the derailment as chaotic and uncontrolled, with one man, Bruno, reporting a loud bang and a cloud of brown smoke.
The Office for the Prevention and Investigation of Accidents in Civil Aviation and Rail (GPIAAF) issued an interim report that is preliminary and not conclusive.
A final report is expected to be released next year, highlighting the need for improved safety standards and oversight in public transport systems.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A deadly crash on the Glória funicular in Lisbon, Portugal, in September 2025, resulted in at least 16 deaths and multiple injuries when a steel cable snapped during operation. Preliminary findings from the Office for the Prevention and Investigation of Accidents in Civil Aviation and Rail (GPIAAF) reveal that the cable failed to meet CARRIS’s operational specifications and lacked required certification for passenger use. The investigation also uncovered serious maintenance failures, including false documentation of completed tasks and a non-compliant maintenance plan. Eyewitnesses described the derailment as chaotic and violent. While the interim findings are preliminary, they highlight critical safety lapses in public transport operations and point to urgent reforms needed in infrastructure oversight and accountability.
title: Cable in deadly Portugal funicular crash failed to meet specifications, preliminary report finds
